qas.question: What determines how fast a tungsten filament evaporates?
What is the typical goal for the life of a tungsten filament bulb?
Which types of lamps may have particularly short lives?
What is the typical tradeoff in light bulb design?
What does not determine how fast a tungsten filament evaporates?

plausible_answers.text: the lifetime of a filament lamp

qas.question: What is not a trade-off between efficiency and longevity?
What type of bulb typically has a life of 3000 hours?
What type of lamp has higher efficiency but are used where the cost is high compared to the value of energy used?
What type of lamp has a useful life of a few days?

context: During ordinary operation, the <b6_0>tungsten<b6_0/> of the filament evaporates; <a0_0><b4_0>hotter, more-efficient filaments<b4_0/> evaporate faster<a0_0/>. Because of this, <b5_0>the lifetime of a filament lamp<b5_0/> is a trade-off between <a3_0>efficiency and longevity<a3_0/>. The trade-off is typically set to provide a lifetime of <a1_0>several hundred to 2,000 hours<a1_0/> for lamps used for general illumination. <a2_0><b8_0>Theatrical, photographic, and projection lamps<b8_0/><a2_0/> may have a useful life of only a few hours, trading life expectancy for high output in a compact form. <b7_0>Long-life general service lamps<b7_0/> have lower efficiency but are used where the cost of changing the lamp is high compared to the value of energy used.
